author: @mr.cleanone3900
comment:
After its launch and the media hype, Hopscotch was attaining phenomenal growth in its number of users; however, the app was still free, so the company didn’t have any revenue. Thus, the company had to raise additional venture capital. Samantha and Jocelyn took Hopscotch through two rounds of funding, in 2013 and again in 2015, and they raised $1.2 million. 

Eventually, the Hopscotch team realized that with continual growth, but lack of revenue, they would need to constantly look for more investment, but they didn’t want to run the risk of going out of business if they couldn’t manage to continue to raise money, so they decided to switch to a paid subscription model.

Not sure why everyone is all up in arms about her not knowing Cuban's daughter uses this app. Two things to note:

Cuban gives a lot of charity, and prefers to be private about what he does and who he helps. It isn't like he and his daughter broadcasted this game.

Second, privacy laws surrounding children are incredibly tough in the US. No sane company deals in children's products. This is why Facebook and other platforms have age requirements. This isn't because these companies give a care, rather, they don't want the legal landmines.

author: @oldandtiredshouldberetired3436
comment: The majority of lemonade stands operate illegally now. There are cottage food regulations passed in more recent years in most states. Children should be taught to operate businesses legally and their legal guardians must file business liscences where applicable like any other business owner. So this app is really not needed kids can use cash pay apps already, but the reason lemonade stands are outta business isn't a digital world it's regulations to control sanitation and safety. One cannot even make lip balm or bath bombs without a home inspection to ensure customer safety. Those offering food sales from home using even one piece of commercial equipment in this county of NC are required to offer public restrooms. So child operated businesses are challenging for a child to truly operate themselves. They need adults to do the majority. Anyhow there are labor laws to consider. Does the child want to run a business or is the child asked to run a business?
